Viral photos of bricks along a sidewalk in Detroit are being posted to social media to claim that the bricks are a deliberate effort to incite violence ahead of possible unrest in the wake of the 2020 election.
"Pictures taken yesterday, 10/21 in Detroit. Lots of bricks," reads a Facebook post with over 900 shares. "Didn’t see any construction in the area. There’s no such thing as a coincidence."
Another user wrote, "bricks randomly placed all over Detroit. Here we go again."
USA TODAY reached out to the users for comment.
Fact check: Pennsylvania voters exposed to COVID-19 can still vote
The owner of a construction company in Detroit has confirmed that the bricks near Wayne State University's Tierney Alumni House are for a screening wall, not for staged riots.
John Hamood, owner of John Hamood Construction Services, told the Detroit Free Press that the bricks were originally at the parking lot of a gas station near the construction site.
He said that after numerous people stopped at the gas station to question the purpose of the bricks, the owner of the gas station asked him to put a cover over them.
“There were not any loose bricks,” Hamood said. “There are metal bands that strap them tightly together.”
Detroit police spokesperson Latrice Crawford told the Detroit Free Press that police received two reports on Monday about piles of bricks in the Wayne State University district.
However, police looked into it and found no bricks at one site and determined that the bricks at the other site were for a construction project.
Fact check: Clip altered to make Barack Obama look confused at Joe Biden campaign event

Similar claims about pallets of bricks went viral in June following riots and protests over the death of George Floyd, a Black man who died after a former white police officer knelt on his neck for almost nine minutes.
The claim was debunked by several fact-checking organizations including Snopes, Factcheck.org and the Associated Press.

Factcheck.org reviewed five different social media posts and found no evidence that the bricks were being staged. In most cases, the bricks were delivered for construction projects or had already been at the sites.
Fact check: Poll watcher turned away at Philadelphia polling station in misunderstanding

There is no evidence that bricks are purposely being staged in Detroit to incite violence. The owner of a construction company in Detroit and police have both confirmed that the bricks photographed are for construction projects. This claim has previously appeared during protests and has been debunked. We rate this claim as FALSE because it is not supported by our research.
